The class distribution in camera trap datasets is often imbalanced, leading to biased models that perform well on majority classes but poorly on minority classes. To address this issue, we employed two-phase training to improve performance on minority classes. We trained a baseline model and four additional models that implemented different versions of two-phase training on a subset of the highly imbalanced Snapshot Serengeti dataset. Our results show that two-phase training can improve performance on many minority classes with limited loss in performance for other classes. Specifically, we found that two-phase training based on majority undersampling increased class-specific F1-scores by up to 3.0%. We also found that two-phase training outperformed oversampling or undersampling alone by 6.1% in F1-score on average. Furthermore, we found that combining over- and undersampling led to better performance than using them individually.

Introduction

A recent report by the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) confirms that biodiversity and ecosystems are deteriorating worldwide. The population sizes of mammals, birds, amphibians, reptiles, and fish have decreased by an average of 68% between 1970 and 2016 across the world. This decline in biodiversity has several causes, including habitat loss due to pollution, species overexploitation, and climate change. Biodiversity is crucial because it is a key indicator of overall healthy ecosystems, which have significant social and economic consequences for humans. In particular, biodiversity and ecosystems influence our water quality, air quality, and climate, and they secure our food production and impact the spread of infectious diseases originating from animals.

Machine learning (ML) can help to more efficiently measure and monitor the well-being of ecosystems and the success of biodiversity conservation efforts. For example, this paper proposes a method for automatic classification of camera trap images, a type of motion-activated camera used in biological studies to estimate animal population density and activity patterns. Since manually labeling large numbers of camera trap images is time-consuming and costly, ML can be used to automatically detect animals and the species to which they belong in images. This work uses Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to classify camera trap images. Training a CNN on a dataset of camera trap images is challenging due to the high intra-class variation caused by differences in backgrounds and the class distribution of camera trap datasets, which is typically highly imbalanced.

This imbalance is inherent to camera trap datasets, reflecting the imbalance of ecosystems, and results in biased classifiers that perform well for a few majority classes but poorly for many minority classes. Classifiers that perform well on all classes would be more valuable to ecologists, and rare or less observed animal species might be of special interest to researchers. Therefore, solutions are needed to mitigate this imbalance when classifying camera trap images. To this end, we use a two-phase training method to mitigate class imbalance, which we apply for the first time to camera trap images in this study. In experiments, we compare it to different data-level class imbalance mitigation techniques and show that it improves performance on minority classes with limited loss in performance for other classes, resulting in an increase in macro F1-score.

Related work

Pioneering studies that automatically classified camera trap images relied on manual feature extraction and smaller datasets. Better and more scalable results were later achieved with deep CNNs and larger datasets. Generally, models trained by these scholars achieve accuracies well above 90%, but the models are biased towards majority classes, which severely affects their class-specific performance. Especially the performance for rare species is poor. Scholars have dealt with this challenge by removing the rare classes from the dataset, using confidence thresholding and expert review, weighted losses, oversampling, and emphasis sampling, or by using a combination of additional image augmentations for rare classes and novel sampling techniques. Although some techniques have improved accuracy for a few rare classes, none have systematically improved accuracy for most rare species. It can be concluded that dealing with class-imbalance in the context of camera trap images remains a challenging problem.
